column27: Safer bicycling.

column46: "Balance" is just code for continued vehicular domination. It needs to be *possible* to drive there, but nothing should be done to make it easy to drive that in any way compromises the pedestrian or bicycle experience.
column47: If all of Telegraph could be like the few blocks at the north end next to the Berkeley campus, that would be a huge win. Instead AC Transit wants to make those blocks harder to walk on so it can move buses faster like on the rest of Telegraph.  Obviously you already know the commercial streets in the Bay Area that are worth going to: Valencia, Polk, 24th Street (SF), Hayes, Haight, Chestnut, Union, Grant, 4th St (Berkeley), etc. What they all have in common is narrower roadways, easier crossings, and slow and difficult driving conditions.

column48: Pedestrian crossing call buttons! Those things are the bane of my existence in Oakland and don't belong in any urban city. column26: The small businesses, the good public transit service, and crosswalks that make crossing the street easier.
column27: Cars slow down– they move much to fast as it is today. This makes outdoor dining less pleasant and makes me scared to cross the street, even when there are crosswalks (and the crosswalks DO help, but don't do enough). I've talked to business owners and they say the same, that cars drive too fast and hardly stop for pedestrians.  I also wish the bike lanes were wider, possibly protected from cars by physical separation like they do in Europe. I see lots of people biking on the street, I don't know how they do it but it would be safer for them. I would be more likely to ride my bike down Telegraph and visit businesses more often if it were easy and safe to zip on down on my bike. The separated bike lanes would also make my bus trips more relaxing since the buses would not constantly be jerking left and right to navigate around folks biking. (the "leap-frogging" between bikes and buses are an other reason why I don't bike much on Telegraph today).
column42: More signalized intersections and force people exiting driveways to make a right.

column46: Vision Statement should prioritize sustainability and safety.
column47: College Avenue in Berkeley/Oakland: Cars move slowly on this street which makes walking and outdoor dining more pleasant. College Avenue isn't great for buses or bikes, but it shows that a business corridor can function just fine when cars move slower. I also like the curb extensions to shorten crossings.  Valencia St in San Francisco: This street is better for bikes than Telegraph is today, and I think that's because the bike lanes are wider and the cars move slower. Valencia St however does not physically separate the bikes, which leaves biking still being somewhat dangerous and scary.  Shattuck Ave in Berkeley's gourmet ghetto: I like the street trees and the mid block crossing by Cheeseboard Pizza. The street has a nice atmosphere that I think Telegraph could emulate.
column48: San Francisco has a lot of parklets, why doesn't Oakland?  Slow the cars down, it's dangerous as it is today. Valencia St and College Ave show that business corridors can thrive when cars move slow.  Physically separate bikes from cars/buses. This would remove conflict, especially with buses (and Telegraph Ave has a lot of buses running on it) and encourage people to bike, and we all benefit when more people bike!

column47: Paris,France. Some of the bike paths to and from the central city of Melbourne, Az. Even have street cars, green cushy bike lanes and timed signals for the cyclists.  Leaving the central city heading north past the Yarra district offices an entire street parallel to the auto thoroughfares, is devoted cycling.  Once the old outer rail line ring, which is an east west class one cycle path, is reached numbers of different bike paths split off the main City bike path. In Uppsala, Sweden, cycling commuters even in the snow, ride on a variety of designated cycle paths of a variety of surface textures, with their own traffic signals.  Some of the routes are on the motor ways but most take advantage of parallel streets, roads, and alleys.  Neither cars nor bikes are allowed on the shopping walking streets. Berlin has so many bike paths, signals,trees, streets of different sizes.  Perhaps the craziness of getting from Charlottesburg south up to the Charlotteschloss mimics the diversity along Telegraph.
column48: Everyone should take a trip to several cities in Europe to gather ideas that work and don,t work Riding in Vilnus along was dangerous.  Riding in Yangshou, China, was delightful... Trees,  shops, pedestrians, cars, push carts, and buses.

column46: I don't know that I agree with the statement that all modes have safety issues. Telegraph Ave has been completed designed for cars and Oakland's traffic engineer has signed off on the current design as being safe. I think bus travel is also safe. However, walking and bicycling are not safe and need improvements.  The vision statement also needs to say something about Telegraph being a great 'place' not just a great thru fare for all travelers.  While past work is good, Telegraph's vision should be much better than past visions, and should say something like Telegraph Avenue should be a world class street on par with great avenues the world over.

column42: 48th Street to 52nd Street Westbound is too congested.  There are large buses stopping in front of Walgreen's, which limits traffic to one lane.  Also, several cars are trying to get into a perpetually crowded parking lot (Walgreen's/Genova Deli, Peet's).  The buses need to be able to pull further off the road - it would be worthwhile to lose a little parking or sidewalk space for the trade off.
column43: I am not using buses.  They are far too dangerous and slow.
column44: The full corridor of Telegraph Ave, from Jack London Square to Ashby is only suitable for very experienced cyclists.  I love bicycling, but riding on Telegraph has already sent me to the hospital (parked car door opened) with two broken ribs and a broken wrist.  What is telling is that the car driver was not terribly concerned about me.  Cars get priority in this corridor, and drivers treat bicyclists and pedestrians as third class citizens.
column45: Things as simple as sidewalk trees make for a pedestrian friendly zone.  Of course, the trees would need to be maintained, not just planted.  Currently, one has to be either poor, or adventurous to spend money (bring revenue to businesses) along the 30th to 60th Street corridor.  I lived at 49th Street for many years, while I was earning a lower middle-class wage, and I am still fond of the area.  But now that we earn middle class wages, I still visit, but my wife and her girlfriends don't feel safe.

column46: Improving the "comfort for...bicycling" is a nice idea but I am most concerned about safety. High visibility bike lanes, trippable taffic lights, pothole fixing, etc. are not simply matters of comfort for bikers - they're matter of life-perserving safety. Not having a visible bike lane leaves me vulnerable for clueless drivers making turns without checking for bikers. btrusive potholes could cause me to unexpectedly serve into traffic. Lights I can't trip on my bike cause me to run red lights because without a car, there's no way to turn it green. Please don't belittle improvments for cyclists as simply "comforts." They are crucial safety mechanisms for creating proper bike infrastructure.
column47: There is no ideal, well traveled road I can think of currently. Again, an ideal Telegraph avenue would have a highly visible (bright green?) bike lanes with enough room that cyclists aren't vulnerable to getting doored (true story - close calls happen on an almost daily basis and I have many friends who've been the cycling victims of careless drivers). An ideal telegraph would also have bike lanes pop up for common left hand turns cyclists take (think the Wiggle in SF). An ideal Telegraph would be well paved and free from uneven surfaces, large cracks and potholes. An ideal Telegraph would have all lights that aren't on an automatic switch be trippable by cyclists. An ideal Telegraph would also have "Share the Road" signs and a special super highly visible bike lane where Shattuck and Telegraph meet (I like to call that the Merge of Death - it's scary stuff!)

column48: Consider the average speed vs. top speed disparity in a place like Telegraph. Because of all the street lights and speed-inducing design, motorists tend to drive above the speed limit and then wait at lights. Their average speed doesn't usually go above 10-15 mph throughout the corridor based on my experience riding my bike and getting through it faster than they do (while running lights). If roundabouts were used to replace streetlights and lanes were shrunk, the top speed would be drastically reduced, while possibly improving average speed.

There needs to be wide bike lanes, although north of 57th is good for having bike lanes, they feel narrow and it still doesn't feel entirely safe.  It would be good to see very well defined bike lanes that are separate from traffic (vs. sharrows) and possibly colored like the 40th st sharrows.  Turning is often difficult on telegraph primarily due to the aggressive nature that many drivers have on long straight dual lane roads like Telegraph.

column47: I liken Telegraph to parts of Market St. in SF where there is a high volume of different transit modes.  There is however a very well demarcated bike lane on Market St (and streetcars! Which would be awesome!)  It would be nice to see bike lanes that were separated from traffic but I see that as being a long term vision.  In the near term, bicycle usage on Telegraph seems to be increasingly steadily and it is time that the City of Oakland takes steps to ensure a balance between bicycling, pedestrians, mass transit, and cars.  I think cars should be the lowest priority focus, there are too many problems with speeding and aggressive driving along Telegraph.  Perhaps traffic calming measures could be an additional component of the plan.
column48: I think Telegraph is the most important street in Oakland in terms of connectivity between downtown and Berkeley, a variety of different neighborhoods that it passes through, and the businesses it supports. column46: I've always been satisfied with pedestrian safety on Telegraph--I can't think of any particularly problematic sections where pedestrians are but at risk, but the issue seems to be how does one balance the safety and access of cars, bikes, and buses at the same time? As a cyclist, tend to stay away from Telegraph since it seems to be not bike-friendly in some places. I'd rather stick to smaller north/south streets (like Bike Boulevards) to get around. Sometimes that's difficult. Regardless, I'd like to see more preference for buses and bikes and less for cars, but then again, due to some of the blocked intersections in surrounding neighborhoods in Berkeley, sometimes the more reliable way to get north or south is Telegraph.

column27: The street section. I wish it had less room for cars and more safe, dedicated, protected space for bicycles & pedestrians. I also wish it had better transit -- streetcar, light rail, or at least bus rapid transit, preferably electric-powered to reduce noise and emissions. I wish it was smooth pavement. I wish it had lower crime. I wish it had more destinations and fewer vacant lots, fewer parking lots, and fewer cars.
column42: Entire length of Telegraph: Remove all traffic lights and replace with traffic circles. Remove a lane of traffic in each direction, no more than one lane is required in each direction.

column44: Entire length of Telegraph: A cycle track between the parking lane and the curb, where parking is present, should be the default configuration. A buffered bicycle lane should be used where there is no on-street parking. Paint and rumble strips should be used to protect the cycle track from turning car traffic at intersections, as well as potentially special signal cycles at major intersections.
column45: Better crosswalks using bulbouts, islands and HAWK signals to facilitate easier crossing; more sidewalk cafes, more seating in PARKlets in the parking strip.
column46: The end result should be to make Telegraph Avenue safe for bicyclists aged 8 to 80, and for pedestrians of any age.
column47: Gammel Kongevej, Copenhagen, Denmark is one example of a street that has continuous protected bicycle lanes or cycle tracks along its length, as well as transit lanes, auto lanes, auto parking where room allows, and a safe pedestrian environment. I would prefer to see more trees along Telegraph, but otherwise this seems like a good example.
column48: The cycle track could either be two way on one side of the street, or one way on both sides of the street. Of the two options, the former might be preferable, given the lower space requirement and the limited available ROW on Telegraph.

column26: It is a major thoroughfare throughout Oakland. Consequently, much of Telegraph Avenue has wonderful businesses in which to patronize. Moreover, it is a great way to commute between Jack London Square and Temescal.
column27: Telegraph Avenue is too car-centric. There are absolutely no police to monitor the behavior of drivers as they run red lights at 42nd and Telegraph and 40th and Telegraph. In addition, as a major thoroughfare through Oakland, there should be some effort to make it a more attractive street. There should be a median with vegetation (e.g., oak trees, native plants). This would make Telegraph prettier and make it such that the street becomes less car-centric. Bike lanes, like the new bike lanes that have appeared on 40th between Broadway and Market, are necessary. And, although this is wishful thinking, Telegraph Ave. would be a great street to consider having a light rail should Oakland want to join the modern age.
column42: Telegraph Ave is primarily a street for drivers to drive in any way they want without any repercussions. Regretfully, this is often at the expense of pedestrians and bicyclists. This is more appropriate for suburbs than for cities.
column43: Many bus stops on Telegraph are inadequate. Compare bus shelters in Oakland to bus shelters in San Francisco or Chicago. All bus stops should provide shelter for passengers. In general, AC Transit lines (e.g., 1 and 1R) run somewhat sporadically. This is less of a problem for people with Smart phones and an AC Transit application, but for passengers who do not have this luxury, some people have to wait a really long time sometimes between buses.
column44: There are certain areas of Telegraph (around both Flying Yoga locations, for example) where there is a large influx of cars parking and leaving throughout the day. Separated bike lanes, like the ones that have appeared in Chicago and Seattle might be helpful in these areas where there are a lot of cars parking and leaving.
column45: Walk lights through major intersections should be activated regardless of pedestrians need to push the walk sign button. There is not not enough time for pedestrians to walk across most streets unless the walk sign is pushed (e.g, 40th and 42nd). This reinforces the notion that pedestrians are regarded not nearly as important as drivers.
column46: This is an impressive vision statement. It seems that the city of Oakland and the Alameda County Transportation Commission are aware of the problems on Telegraph Ave. I hope to be able to experience the outcome of this vision statement in the near future.
column47: Milwaukee Ave in Chicago, IL; Ainsworth St. or Mississippi Ave in Portland, OR; Pine / Pike in Seattle, WA; S. Broadway in Denver, CO.

column48: I struggled with the question #9 on whether or not the current configuration is acceptable.  I took the question to mean more than simply basic cross-section & lane geometry, assuming you also mean the current treatments and amenities for various users.  In that sense, and regardless of the final number of lanes, Telegraph needs a lot of work to become a nicer "promenade" style street: upgraded street furniture & lighting, parklets to extend the sidewalk width at key locations, swales & trees to add more natural elements.  Consider a landscaped median where space permits to improve the feeling of human-scale.

column26: - some parts are lined with nice trees  - in some parts cars travel at a speed that feels safe to be near  - nice variety of businesses, relatively few chain stores
column27: - I wish there was some humane and inviting public space to take a break in or people-watch from, ideally adjacent to things that make people want to linger rather than being bordered by noisy smoggy streets and parking.  A public square or plaza on the East side, maybe in place of the "Dollar Cleaner" store and/or parking lot near 49th St. would be nice, especially if it was designed to accommodate a variety of cultural, commercial, and recreational activities.  - Let's build on the success of Temescal Alley, and either find ways to link it back to Telegraph Ave or to new pedestrian spaces  - Make it either more convenient and quick to cross by bike (good) or add cycle tracks, which is the only safe, long term solution that will get people of all ages to ride (better!)  - The freeway overpass @ 56th divides the neighborhood by discouraging bikes and pedestrians from crossing.  Something needs to be done to mitigate the unpleasant environment it creates.  (Also, space beneath a freeway is a terrible place to put public parks, so it could be kept as open green space or for a light industrial use.)

column46: This is a very timid statement as it seems to strive for 100% consensus, which usually leads to very mild and bland improvements that for the most part maintain the status quo.  You need to acknowledge that making streets that are safe for your 8-year old and your 80-year old to walk through, for people of most ages to bike through, and that are inviting and engaging will NOT make travel easier for cars.  Do you want to fight for transformative change that will apply proven design solutions from other forward-thinking cities, or are we going to end up with a meek redevelopment that will get torn up again in a few decades when some bad urban planning ideas finally die off?  Let's not water down some of the potential we have here!

Improved bicycle and pedestrian safety also must be prioritized over comfort/convenience of driving due to the great exposure that exists for people who are not protected by a heavy steel cage.  Oakland should not be a place where you have to drive to feel safe.  If Oaklanders wanted that to be the case, they would move to the suburbs.

column27: Pedestrian paths. These are to be level at all intersections, No ups or downs.   The raised path slows cars down at the intersections. This if for all parts of the road, at all intersections cross walks, and all sides of a junction.    These will act as traffic calming measures, and ensure that pedestrian right of way. This slows cars at the most likely interaction between car and pedestrian interaction.  A protected bike lane, next to the pedestrian path. with standing gap/ridge, for passanger door car opening.  Then car parking. With a bus lane next  The Bus lane,  this will come with a raised platform which is fully enclosed. with pay gates at the entrance, with cash, and fast pass card reader. this can be camera enforced.   At each bus stop, there is an Enclosed prepay shelters. These are raised to be level with the floors of the bus, there is no step up. There is to be a small platform,  that allows immediate access with those with walkers and wheel chairs, there could be self guiding bumps that direct how the bus comes to these bus stops, the buses for this route will be dedicated for this route, there will be no requirement for a cash machine or card readers on board the bus.   These bus stops come with restrain doors, that only open after the bus gets there, once the bus arives every one can board off board with no time taken for cash or card payments as you on-board, as that has taken place before bus arives. This will make a major time for transit change, as to cash/card payment, while on boarding, this will save about 1/3 to 1/2 of transit time. Also the platform will again speed on/off boarding as there are no steps involved. people will be able to move onto the bus far faster by about 10 seconds per passenger. Aka Curcubit or Bogatar.    With in transit lane, I want Lights, that are driven by the buses.  Giving them consistent  override and movement, If there is a red light, it is done so that, a bus is waiting at the bus platform.   Once all boarding has taken place, the light turns green, and the bus moves off.    For Cars this will leave no slow moving transport, it will leave cleaner site lines, and more constant traffic patterns. there will be a calmer transit speed as the raised paved intersections will mean that the speed will remain constant. It will mean also that these will act gas saving measures as cars will not be using jack rabbit starts. the up and then down will mean a more steady driving will be encouraged.

column45: Bulb-outs would be great to reduce pedestrian cross time. Also, can we automate the lights so that they automatically turn green for pedestrians? A pedestrian can wait all he wants, he's always going to have to wait at an intersection - a green light will never be waiting for him/her.

column26: I love that Telegraph is a community destination that serves a population that is very interested in a pedestrian based urban lifestyle. The restaurants and cafes and our new Temescal Alley exemplifies the great things about our community.  Our neighborhood is filled with families and individuals who value community and the arts. This is not a community who wants to have chain stores and large retailers, we value our local businesses and small start up retailers and cafes. Maintaining that is crucial to the keeping Temescal an attactive place to live.
column27: I wish that there were more of what is already there, and less empty storefronts. I would like to see even more restaurants, and most importantly a great small grocery store. I would love to see the fast food gone, as they attact car based culture and disrupt vast swaths of pedestrian storefronts. They break up the avenue in odd chunks. and more local retailers. There are several large vacant buildings surrounding 49th and telegraph that need to be addresses, the current owners let the graffitti build up and become eyesores. More small scale apartment housing could replace these vacancies and bring more life to the avenue.
column44: a green bike lane like on 40th. This approach is excellent. Until i becan pregnant, I commute along 40th over to emeryville and up to North Berkeley. The green bike lane finally respects the fact that cyclist have the same rights as cars. It will take some time for motorist to get used to the idea, but having the green paint is a constant reminder to motorists that bicyclist belong in the middle of the lane where they can be seen, they do not belong along the side of the street to be passed closely at highspeed and easily ignored. This will be an adujustment for AC transit and motorist but at the benefit of public health and safety. Many young people in the community have no idea of basic biking laws and ride the wrong direction, on sidewalks etc- perhaps painting on the roads where bikes belong will help teach them better safer biking habits. This applies to the entire corridor.
column47: I think that Telegraph could resemble more urban infilled streets like Valencia in San francisco that have one lane traffic each way, and designated bike lanes. column26: I think it is a great destination.  I love the shops and restaurants.  I enjoy how it changes as you travel along the road.
column27: I wish the adjacent streets were safer to walk along after dark.    Also, when I first moved to the Shafter neighborhood years ago, I began biking along Telegraph Ave to my place of work downtown.  However, I nearly got into a few accidents with buses.  The major issue was that buses would travel faster than me on my bike, but would make frequent stops.  This would cause use to leap frog each other.  Due to their large size, the buses would frequently squeeze me between it and the parked cars.  I now use the Shafter/Webster route.  Improvements to this parallel route could work as a good compromise to improve bike transportation along the corridor.
column45: Improve the safety where possible, such as by adding additional lighting to increase walk-ability from nearby neighbourhoods.
column46: I think that the project vision statement is good.    Regarding the lack of space for cyclists, improvements could be made to the already existing Webster/Shafter bike route that runs parallel to Telegraph.    The Webster/Shafter route works well, but could be improved.  It is already well used by bikes, but signing could be added to Telegraph to alert bikes to the route.  The bikes would then have to use the cross streets to access Telegraph.  Sufficient bike parking is always appreciated.  Also, there are some speed bumps along the bike route.  These can be difficult for bicyclists to navigate.  There are speed bump designs that include a notch for bikes that could be alternatively used.  The stop signs or street lights along the Webster/Shafter route at every block can be difficult for bikes.  If there was a way to provide preference to this route, while stopping cross traffic, this would greatly improve the bike-ability.    If there was a way to designate one of these parallel streets as a bicycle boulevard (similar to those in Berkeley), it would make it easier for bikers and reduce conflicts.  Local traffic would definitely still need access to the Webster/Shafter route, but all through traffic could be moved to Telegraph/Broadway.  In addition to the housing, there are also a couple of schools in the area that bring vehicular traffic.  Improvements could be adding green paint to combine with the "sharrows" to emphasize the bike route.  Also frequent speed bumps with bicycle notches could be used to slow down/deter cars on the bicycle boulevard.

column48: I just wanted to share a story about the benefits of protecting bike traffic from vehicular traffic on Telegraph Avenue. Though I primarily commute by bicycle, one afternoon last spring, I was actually riding in our car with my husband on our way to an appointment. We were driving north on Telegraph Avenue, approaching 41st Street. The car in front of us was driving erratically, sort of floating far right and far left in its lane. I wondered if the driver was drunk and was about to call the police from my cell phone. As we approached the stoplight at 41st, the car in front veered so far to the right that it basically caused a woman bicyclist also approaching that light to brake suddenly and come to a complete stop so that she would not be smushed between the parked cars and this car. I shook my head and assumed that this car wanted to turn right and didn't see this bicyclist and cut her off. But to my surprise, the car does not turn and continues up Telegraph. The bicyclist, sensing this car is dangerous, rides up onto the sidewalk after crossing 41st (which I generally frown upon because it's unfair to pedestrians), but in this case it's a good thing she did, because the next thing we see is that this car continuees to careen in the lane and actually sideswipes the row of parked cars, completely knocking off the side mirror of a large truck. We chased down the car and called the police and gave them the license plate. The driver ended up parking in the Koryo lot and got out: a very elderly woman. I am not even sure if she knew she actually hit a bunch of cars. But if that bicyclist had not taken the sidewalk, she would be dead.

column46: It would be great if the vision could touch upon prioritizing certain modes. I don't know if that is within the intent of the project, but I believe if the Complete Streets approach is to be fully adopted, then the more "sustainable" modes of transportation (transit, cycling, and walking) need to be prioritized over cars. This would inevitably mean cars would need to slow down, which generally goes against what motorists want. However, the implicit purpose of Complete Streets is to make a place more livable - which includes being a place where people want to come and stay - and a slower paced (human-scale) environment is what I believe will achieve a livable environment.

column26: Street has lots of what I need (stores, etc.).  Pretty decent "street feel".  Street "scale" is good: I like the bldgs of 2 to 4 stories, which provide enough people to support transit & make things not feel lonely, but not so many people as to overwhelm.  Such streetscapes are common on the parts of Telegraph I use most often (55th Street to 40th Street).  The street lets me get from here to there, most of the time, without major delay, by bus or driving (contrast: College Avenue, Piedmont Avenue).  Has left-turn lanes in most places where needed (south of Hwy 24).  Removing those left-turn lanes was proposed, to make more space for other things; this is a *bad idea*. I hate to hold up other motorists, which I'd have to do a lot, if the left turn lanes were removed.  Sidewalks have adequate width (contrast: Piedmont Ave. sidewalks are too narrow).  Transit service is about as good as it gets, and I use it fairly often, even though I have a car and good parking.  Telegraph has good alternate route for bicyclists (Shafter/Webster) between 51st St. & 27th St.
column27: Congestion, especially at rush hours between 48th St. & on-ramp to Hwy 24 eastbound.  Traffic signals at shopping center (former 50th), 51st, and 52nd/Claremont are very close together, tending toward gridlock; could these signals could be better coordinated?  Also, could we prohibit left turns for cars going north on Telegraph, turning left onto 52nd?  These particular turns favor gridlock, and there's a good alternate route, but some cars do this turn to save a few seconds, at the cost of delaying other cars. Wait time for pedestrian crossing at shopping center (former 50th) is so long that I'm tempted to jaywalk.  When driving, I sometimes have to worry about collisions with bicycles.  Lane striping is badly faded in spots.  Litter is an issue, esp. near 40th Street.  (Also, I wish our country didn't have so many hungry people - that's visible on Telegraph - but ending poverty is outside the scope of your work.)
column42: Signal improvements and no-left-turn (48th to 52nd), see #7. Re parking: The big lot around the Walgreen's at 51st St. is open to customers of businesses outside that shopping center (which I really like), but other parking lots lack this freedom.
column43: At 49th St. northbound, remove a couple of parking spaces to better accommodate 60-foot buses. Rapid service (1R) is usually fast, but subject to bus-bunching.
column44: Improvements to alternate routes.  In particular: 1. Underpass where Webster passes under I-580 needs better lighting & cleaning, at least.  2. Signage on this route. 3. Signal needed at Ashby & Hillegass, Berkeley - I've heard it will happen.
column45: Street lighting is inadequate in a few spots, esp. just north of Aileen Street.
column46: As is, the statement ignores the Hillegass/Colby-Shafter/Webster bicycle route.  That route is an essential element of any Telegraph Corridor study as pertains to bicycles.  The question to ask for bicycles isn't necessarily a better experience *on Telegraph* (in the stretch south of 55th Street), but how to make bicycling better when going north-south *somewhere near Telegraph.*  Remember, any major improvement *for bicycles on Telegraph* will interfere severely with transit and driving.
column48: Re transit: A few years ago, AC looked at bus rapid transit along Telegraph.  Under current circumstances, BRT on Telegraph would have been a mistake, and I think AC got that.  In future decades, cars may be less feasible.  When that happens, people might really switch more trips to transit/rideshare/bicycle, which are more efficient for street space, emissions, etc., but less efficient for time, ability to carry things, safety, etc.

column26: It's a great area to live in, walkable despite being a major roadway. Great little shops, wonderful restaurants, convenient access to places I want to go both locally (via bus, foot) and farther out (BART, car).
column27: The roadway is in significant disrepair, relevant to all users including pedestrians (I've uncomfortably twisted an ankle on account of the irregular, deteriorating pavement).   I also really wish the bus access to downtown Oakland and Berkeley was better. The BRT project was an amazing opportunity to be a national leader in creating efficient public transit within a shared road space, but of course, the NIMBYs on the north end of the project blew it. Such a disappointment, because any improvements to the bus system are a huge win for convenience and livability along one of the major corridors between the two downtowns.
column42: The unprotected left from EB40th to NB Telegraph is a comically bad decision for traffic flow.
column43: Some of the bus stops are dumpy. Improved signange, lighting, arrival notifications, and shelters are needed for most of the study area. The shelter at SB Telegraph & 22nd or so has vanished completely after damage or vandalism. No physical stop structure NB from that area, either, perhaps owing to sidewalk width. Service is frequent on paper, which is great, but sometimes can get incredibly jammed up, with 3, 4, or even 5 (yes, I've seen it) 1 / 1R buses clumped together, followed by NextBus reporting no 1/1R for upwards of 20-25 minutes. Unacceptable for basically the highest-frequency service corridor AC Transit manages.
column44: I don't bicycle on Telegraph, and you couldn't pay me enough to. It's a road built for cars and no one else, and everyone drives like it. It's too wide, it encourages traffic to go to fast, and there is basically NO visible allowance for non-motorized traffic on the street. It's scary.
column45: If you want this to be a pedestrian-friendly corridor, get rid of the "push to cross" buttons at EVERY intersection. Give pedestrians the green light each cycle in just the same way that you do for cars. Continue to improve lighting along the way (the north end in the 40s has those new LEDs that are spiffy and energy-efficient -- keep it up!). Trash bins and benches along the way might also help encourage both foot traffic and foot/bus combination travelers.
column46: I like this. I'm not anti-car -- I own one and I use it, because at times it's incredibly convenient, so I'm very aware of and sympathetic to people who value that feature.   But let's not kid ourselves, either, by pretending that automobile traffic on Telegraph in the study area needs to be any sort of priority for this project. As it stands, automobile traffic is basically the *only* priority for travel in the study area (1R stops with LED arrival time signs aside). Almost any modification made to the corridor is going to be to the detriment of automobile traffic as a result. Any change to this vision statement should at least consider acknowledging it's the (speeding, unsafe, or unaware) automotive traffic that is going to be "detrimentally" affected by the improvements made -- and that's just fine.
column47: I hear SF is getting BRT on Van Ness.  *cough, cough*  Seriously, though, look at Melbourne. Look at Curitiba. Hell, look at LA -- LA!  There are ways to mix and integrate effective, efficient, popular, and rapid mass transit into corridors like this. There's no reason we shouldn't expect Oakland can manage the same.

column27: The intersection of Telegraph and 51st is a mess. The root of the problem is the proximity of the lights on Telegraph at 51st and at Claremont. Having both of these lights so close together and having them not optimally timed means that often cars turning left from 51st to head north on Telegraph end up blocking the intersection. Awful. A total reconfiguration of the intersection should be done. Also, I wish there were dedicated, separate bike lanes all the way along Telegraph from its beginning in Berkeley through its terminus in downtown Oakland.

column47: Making Telegraph into a skinnier version of Mandela Parkway would be AWESOME! That's not reasonable, though, given width restrictions. I'd suggest eliminating one lane of travel in each direction to make room for a dedicated bike lane. One travel lane in each direction plus a center lane for turns is more than enough. Also, the intersection with Shattuck is very dangerous for bicyclists traveling south on Telegraph because of the merge of traffic. Perhaps southbound traffic on Shattuck could be diverted to a forced left at 47th street, the portion of Shattuck between 46th and the merge with Telegraph could be made into a park like Latham Square, and the portion of Shattuck between 46th and 47th could be made one-way (northbound).

column46: The Vision Statement should also say something about the nature of the neighborhoods and businesses that are adjacent to and within this corridor. There are more young families, young working people, and elderly residents, all of whom have an interest in encouraging accessibility to restaurants, galleries, medical services, and small businesses without having to deal with the pollution and safety hazards caused by excessive motor vehicle traffic, which historically has been the default favorite. We need to change this.
column47: In both Oakland and Berkeley, there have been efforts to integrate the natural environment with man-made roads and other transportation systems by adding trees, plants, and other creative landscaping to "soften" and enhance the experience of using and crossing along these corridors by foot, bicycle or motor vehicle. column48: We have a unique opportunity at this time, when the neighborhoods, businesses and services along Telegraph are undergoing a "renaissance" of activity for an amazingly diverse group of citizens (racially, culturally, and economically). column45: Because of the width of Telegraph Ave. (necessary to carry all the traffic that exists), bulb-outs at intersections could help pedestrians in crosswalks. The short segment of 52nd St., where it passes by the Temescal Branch Library, could be closed off to vehicular traffic. As it is now, cars turning right onto 52nd St. From Telegraph (typically heading to the freeway entrance just beyond MLK) are a menace to pedestrians crossing 52nd St., despite its short width. Perhaps a small parking lot could replace that short segment of 52nd St., providing library patrons a place to park. The traffic signal at 49th St., controlling access and egress at the Temescal Plaza Shopping Center (Walgreens), is often not seem by drivers on Telegraph. Anything making both that signal and the pedestrian crossing more visible would be a help to pedestrians.

column46: Dedicated bike lanes work fine south of 40th and north of Claremont.  Between those two streets, a bike through way on Webster would be safer for all concerned.  Many intersections in Temescal do not have adequate crosswalks - they either don't exist or are poorly marked or lit.  Pedestrian safety has not kept up with the commercial resurgence.  The NB bus-stop at 49th should be relocated to the SE corner so the articulated buses do not block the crosswalk and intersection.  The intersection of Shattuck and Telegraph should be realigned per the 2005 streetscape plan, creating a plaza where Shattuck now flows between 46th and 45th.  Signage should direct traffic going to the freeway on-ramp at 52nd and Shattuck to take Shattuck from 46th.  That would relieve congestion in the Temescal Commercial District.
column47: Buses control traffic signals in many transit oriented cities, but they have only limited control in Oakland.  I think they should be able to force a green light whenever they approach an intersection (except when at a bus stop) to give buses priority and reduce bus bunching.

column47: It should be like 14th st in DC. it has good bike lanes, a circulator bus route to downtown, and lots of pedestrian-oriented businesses.  I like streets like Piedmont and College avenue but Telegraph is a different animal. It's less cloistered and quaint and more urbane and cosmopolitan.  I see people on it from all over the city and maybe the East Bay. It brings Oakland together. People come to Telegraph to work, for nightlife, and to get through town. I think that makes it unique in the Bay Area. It's like Market Street in San Francisco, but Telegraph is better because it gets more sunlight and isn't as windy. I think it's one of Oakland's greatest assets!

A bike lane is greatly needed! Also, there are WAY too many vehicles that double park along telegraph, including private vehicles and those that are loading/unloading deliveries to businesses. They often do this despite curb space being available to park. So better enforcement of this issue would also be extremely helpful.

column48: I see you mentioned speeding as an issue in your vision statement, but keep in mind that there is also a constant issue with people who drive almost ten miles below the speed limit on Telegraph as well (around 10-15mph). Often these people cause severe traffic congestion. Sometimes it is because they are looking for parking, other times it is because they appear under the influence/impaired in some way, appear to be actively texting/on the phone, or simply are worried about looking out for pedestrians or bicyclists. Having telegraph expanded to six lanes instead of four would be ideal, although I'm sure this is probably not logistically possible. Better traffic enforcement of those who drive under the influence or use cell phones while driving might be helpful, as will making more room for bicycles (bike lanes).

column48: Until last year I walked to work daily on Telegraph from 51st to 17th. The most notable hazards were caused by bicyclists riding fast on the sidewalk. As a sometimes  cyclist I understand the need to do this, some areas of the street are too dangerous. But sometimes it's necessary bike-walk, especially near intersections.  The most dangerous problem I noted, time and time again, is when I was on the east side of Telegraph, headed south waiting to cross at the 51st intersection. Before the walk light comes on the south bound traffic on Telegraph has a left turn arrow. Drivers at the curb, in front of me wanting to turn right from westbound 51st onto northbound Telegraph would stare at me as I waited for my southbound walk light, as if to say, "well, what are you waiting for?" Many times as my walk light came on they would start their right turn, giving me a "you idiot" look. People trying to eliminate this hazard by crossing to the 51st median during the left-arrow presented a hazard to the drivers turning left on the arrow (from southbound Telegraph to eastbound 51st), sometimes causing cautious drivers to stop during their turn.

column46: The vision statement should more explicitly de-emphasize cars in favor of the other modes. Telegraph is the main street of North Oakland and the most direct way for pedestrians, bicyclists, and transit users to connect between downtown and North Oakland. Cars travel faster than these other modes, so diverting to other streets is less of a hassle. Drivers can choose any one of dozens of north-south traffic lanes connecting downtown to North Oakland, and be relatively indifferent to their route, but for the other modes there is only one Telegraph Ave. As a neighborhood resident I want Telegraph to be a nice place to walk and shop and live my life, but the current car focus makes the street an unpleasant place. Unfortunately, there's no way that it can both continue to be a speed highway and also become a real neighborhood center. Please be more explicit in stating that this project is designed to enhance the public realm and improve the safety, comfort, and ease of pedestrian, bike, and transit access.
column47: The Bay Area doesn't have any great streets. That's why we badly need this project to be well designed. The street I wish Telegraph most resembled is the street that was proposed as part of the full length East Bay Bus Rapid Transit Project. That project would have done a great job of improving biking, walking, and transit, while maintaining reasonable and appropriate levels of car access. Please try to design a project that adds bike lanes now, but which also could accommodate bus-only lanes in the future (when bus lanes may become more politically and financially feasible).
column48: The new intersection at Telegraph and Hawthorne is fine for cars, but a disaster for pedestrians! Please correct this intersection and don't let others end up this way.  Pedestrians used to have two legal (but unmarked) crossings, now they only have one. Crossing from the south to the south of the intersection now requires crossing two intersections, not one. The push button means pedestrians often have to wait an extra cycle to cross. In an area where a lot of people are elderly and/or disabled it is now much more difficult to legal connect from many of the medical buildings to the Oasis Market and other nearby stores.

column48: An example of the effects of the flower pots:  I live on Derby between Fulton and Ellsworth.  We take the cats to the vet at Fulton and Haste.  We have to go east on Derby, turn left on Telegraph, and turn left off Telegraph onto Haste.  If Fulton weren't blocked, we could go straight up Fulton to Haste.  The route we have to take is about twice as long; I measured it on the map.  It takes much longer because of the left turns on and off Telegraph in heavy traffic.  Multiply that by thousands of cars per day, and you get a huge amount of unnecessary mileage, fuel use, and pollution.

They are beautiful, they give shade, they help absorb noise and they help clear the air.

The only one that even comes close is from just after 51st to about Ashby, and that's only because it has a marked bike lane on it.
column42: traffic congestion seems worst in the Temescal area.  If Telegraph is going to be an artery, then the Temescal should have less traffic control, if it's not, then it should be more obvious to drivers that it's a bad route.

column44: I tell my newer cycling friends to avoid Telegraph like the plague.  It's definitely perceived as one of the more dangerous routes between Berkeley and Oakland.  The street quality is terrible through the Temescal and from around 27th on down.  There are no bike lanes in a lot of areas, which makes fast-moving motor vehicle traffic feel entitled to buzz cyclists and honk at us for being on the road at all.  The high speed of motor vehicle traffic makes it difficult to make left turns with traffic at a lot of locations.
column45: Perception of safety is not contiguous along the street.  I know that this is something that you can't really do a huge amount to change.  Compare the Temescal from 51st to 40th.  It gets progressively less walkable as you get closer to 40th.  Ease of crossing is also kind of a problem above 51st on towards Berkeley.  There are too many reasons to J-walk because crossings are so much less frequent, but making more would slow traffic down unacceptably.
column46: Honestly, pedestrians are out in the cold here.  There are specific portions of Telegraph that will work for them, but the street as a whole is not walkable.  It's too spread out.  The reality is that 'pedestrian friendly' Telegraph is just a place where people can park their cars next to their destination.  One of the things I like about Telegraph is that it is spread out, and encompasses such a large area.  It's a different street block by block.  But that makes it unlike a traditional walkable downtown because you have to cover a lot more distance.
column47: As much as I hate to say it, Piedmont does a pretty good job at all the things mentioned here except 'motorist friendly' streets.  It's very walkable for a short distance, it has a good mix of 'consumer' businesses, as opposed to industrial and heavy commercial business like repair shops.  I think that Shattuck up in North Berkeley has a similar 'walkable' feel to it while staying cyclist and motor vehicle friendly.  In San Francisco, Valencia has tried to strike a balance between different transit forms, and I think it's done relatively well.  The bike lanes are wide, and there's a lot of interaction between cyclists, motor vehicles, and pedestrians, but I think that it's relatively safe, as compared to other streets with that kind of volume.  Transit occurs one street over, on Mission, which seems to be a good way to keep Valencia 'cleaner', in the sense of having traffic flow more consistently.

column46: I feel like these plans are often ambitious and sound good, but when it comes down to it, automobiles still take priority. We live in a society where cars dominate, and we need to take extra effort to combat car dependency and walkable neighborhoods. While I think cars need to be able to travel safely along Telegraph, I think through traffic should be discouraged by having one lane of travel in each direction for cars. The other lanes would be used for buses, for bike lanes, and for wider sidewalks.  A good example of this was the Lake Merritt improvement project. While I think the Lake Merritt dam replacement project was a huge step in the right direction, it still left behind a giant street meant for cars. If we really want to reduce car usage, we need to dedicate more resources to non-auto travel. Instead of building a giant road, maybe we could have built improved bus stops or some sort of BRT along that part of the lake (even though it would have been short in length).
column47: I think Glenview is a great example of what Telegraph could be like. There are lots of shops, and residential housing. Telegraph at 51st is also a good location to model the rest of the street after. The Dimond District is another place where a 4 lane road was reduced to a 2 lane road successfully.

column47: This is rather obscure, but all the streets in Bruges, Belgium are fantastic somehow. Public buses use only certain roads to get in and out of the city and I never notice them as a cyclist or pedestrian. We used the bus a couple of times too and they came at regular and convenient times. All the streets are single lane too, yet it feels perfectly safe to ride on a bike (and yes, I road my own road bike around Bruges) and cross the street as a pedestrian. On a separate trip, we rented a car and drove in and out, but it never felt overly congested, or full of traffic even though it's a tourist destination. I would say parking is limited though. But definitely we road our bikes there for a week and never had a problem or felt unsafe. The streets are magical somehow.

column27: I wish it were safer for bicycles. I love going to the Temescal First Friday events  with my family. We also like to eat dinner at many places on Telegraph. We take the AC Transit bus to my daughter's school in Temescal. We sometimes ride bikes, but would ride more often if it were safer. We really like the cycle tracks like the one planned for Broadway in Oakland, and has been built in San Francisco:  https://www.ebbc.org/caldecott http://sf.streetsblog.org/2010/05/10/san-francisco-gets-its-first-green-bike-lanes-on-market-street/  We'd love to see a cycle track on Telegraph Avenue. Having Bay Area Bicycle Share stations would be a great compliment to cycle tracks:  http://bayareabikeshare.com  It would be more effective if it were tied into Clipper Card!  Also, I was disappointed that the full Bus Rapid Transit plan was not adopted along Telegraph. I would be very happy with anything that moves us in that direction. I'd love to see fewer cars and parking spaces. I've love to see more cycle tracks, transit and parklets like the one on 40th Street:  http://blog.ouroakland.net/2012/11/celebrating-new-40th-street-parklet.html  Finally, I've been happy with the plans for the Oakland Streetcar:  http://www.oaklandstreetcarplan.com  A light rail line on Telegraph would be great.

column46: I strongly disagree with this "vision statement." It's ridiculous victim-speak that has little connection to Telegraph's reality. I find that Telegraph works very well for me as a cyclist and transit rider. As a pedestrian, I would like more-responsive crossing signals and flashing lights. As a motorist (and this also affects bus riders), the real problem is not speed but congestion -- Telegraph functions significantly below its capacity and potential, because slow motorists (loony left turners) block the passing lane. Telegraph is a vital, unique regional lifeline -- you must NOT narrow its capacity or slow it down for fad notions of the alleged victimhood of people using certain modes of transit.
column47: Physically, I like Telegraph the way it is. Economically, I would like to see it a bit more prosperous, with fewer business vacancies and more vitality. However, I would not like to see it gentrified. I think that the Temescal district, the de-facto Koreatown from about 25th Street north, and Geary Blvd. in San Francisco's Outer Richmond District are good models for the rest of Telegraph: A broad boulevard with swift-moving traffic, but with a diversity of affordable, local-serving businesses and services that create a welcoming pedestrian environment.
column48: Please don't fix what ain't broke. Do not reduce Telegraph's lane count, capacity, or speed. Do provide better crossing signals for pedestrians. We cannot have it both ways: either Telegraph Avenue is a major transportation corridor or it is a provincial disaster. I vote for making it a viable high-speed transportation corridor!
column43: buses do not run often enough, and their schedules are completely unreliable. BRT now!
column44: Bicyclists should be provided alternate/parallel roads. The Telegraph corridor is too congested to support bicycles at all!
column45: The only solution here is the one thing that nobody seems to be willing to do in California: RESTRICT PEDESTRIAN ACCESS. BUILD PEDESTRIAN OVERCROSSINGS. AND ENFORCE THE LAW: assign community police officers to TICKET PEDESTRIANS WHO BREAK THE RULES.
column46: You have already failed with this statement. SPEEDING IS A SYMPTOM OF A BIGGER PROBLEM. Simply "slowing down the flow of traffic" does NOT solve anything for anyone. It creates more road-rage and actually makes the roadway MORE dangerous for everyone. The solution is to restrict access from the side-streets and RAISE the speed-limit, plus re-time the stoplights to keep traffic flowing. The Bay Area makes this mistake over and over again: the solution to gridlock is to improve traffic flow. NOT to stop it. Say what you want about suburban Los Angeles, but they do it right there.
column47: I wish that Telegraph Avenue was more like some of the major thoroughfares in the San Fernando Valley in Los Angeles. You can actually USE those streets to get places smoothly and quickly. As it is now, Telegraph Avenue is a joke. It's a patchwork quilt of poorly functioning infrastructural mistakes. The only solution is to STOP this "nimby"-type thinking. Make it difficult to get OFF Telegraph Avenue into the neighborhoods around the avenue, and make it IMPOSSIBLE to cross Telegraph except at large cross-streets. There is no other viable solution that will make traffic flow more smoothly -- including public transit. I have taken the AC Transit 1-bus during BART strikes, all the way from San Leandro to Berkeley. One day it took 55 minutes, and the next day it took 1 HOUR AND 35 MINUTES. This is ridiculous. It's another example of how the Bay Area's infrastructure is trying to be both "California-fast" and small-town provincial and ending up just being the laughing-stock of urban America. PLEASE try to actually FIX it rather than replicating what the city of San Leandro is doing near the San Leandro BART station ("beautifying" San Leandro Boulevard by REDUCING traffic capacity and creating gridlock where there never had been any before).

column48: I would like to see some sort of wayfinding treatment applied to the intersections that connect my neighborhood (Longfellow) to Telegraph Avenue (45th, 42nd, 40th and West Mac). I feel that something colorful at those pedestrian crossings would help provide an identity that these intersections are connectors to our area. Many residents of Longfellow patronize the businesses along Telegraph Avenue and we access these intersections daily via the freeway underpass. Work similar to Roadsworth http://roadsworth.com/home/ could be a good example of an inexpensive, fun wayfinding application. Also, the use of color and paint could tie in nicely with Temescal's existing themed "flow" project.  Also, the cultural landscapey side of my brain would love to see the Complete Street Design Concept pay homage to the rich history in our area regarding the Key Route System. Railroad tracks for ped. crossings, bus stops with site furnishings from that time period, kiosks that explain the history of the area that could allow for walking tours and play etc. etc. etc. Aesthetically, it would be wonderful if the new "system" could provide some sort of window into what was once there.

column46: The corridor has prioritized autos over pedestrians and bicyclists and is flanked on the west side by the freeway. A balance needs to be created between auto uses and  pedestrians, bikes and other transport. In addition to improving safety, studies and anecdotes show that pedestrian, bike and public transit-friendly streets attract more activity and commercial commerce even when they reduce parking, so safety is one issue. Economic development is another that applies on the Telegraph corridor and the plan should not only improve safety, but also commerce. Some merchants will balk at this, but they only need see successful commercial corridors that have reduced parking to know that it's accurate.
column47: In SF: Valencia; Fillmore; Haight; 24th; 22nd; Mission, Clement. Many commercial streets in New York and Europe. The main thing about these streets is that the sidewalks are wide and pedestrian/bike friendly and the streets are more narrow. They have good public transport and bike lanes. They have dense development and commercial spaces that attract a lot of people for different needs and interests and therefore create a vibrant, dynamic environment. Planning 101.
column48: How much money would the public agree to spend on needed improvements? Does the public believe the city should seek grant money to make improvements? Does the public consider street design and related issues in the context of broader city issues, such as crime, safety and public health? If so, to what extent?  Also, you didn't mention much about the history. Why is the street the way it is now? How has it been at different periods in history? How "healthy" was it during those times? Also, what are the next steps in this process? Is the city actually going to do anything?

column26: My neighbors. The people who live here.
column27: Too much traffic = too much pollution! I'd like to see no vehicles other than public transportation.  NO PESTICIDES used on median strips, or anywhere, under any circumstances, period! Honor the spirit of the city's pesticide ordinance, and eliminate all exemptions to it. Every year Public Works pesticide applications are a toxic assault on our neighborhood.  Too many cell towers, antennas, and other wireless installations (including 'Smart' meters) in the area = too much electrosmog!  Not enough vegetation. I'd like to see more trees and other plants growing everywhere, especially edible plants that can help feed our neighborhood.  I would be able to spend more time on Telegraph Ave if the pollutants were eliminated. They are the reason I don't spend more time there.
column42: There is too much traffic. I would frequent the area more if there was less pollution. I would favor a car free area.
column43: Public transit should be a priority over individual motorists. Busses should not sit with motors idling for long. Bus stops should be comfortable, with shelters from the elements, and no smoking signs.
column44: Bike lanes should be a priority over individual motorists, and cars and busses should not be allowed to access them ever. Too many bicyclists get hit by cars! Also make room for skateboarders to travel more safely.
column45: Pedestrians should be the number one priority. Sidewalks should be wide enough and clutter free to easily accommodate wheelchairs and others with mobility challenges. Cross walks should explicitly give pedestrians the right of way, or cars should be eliminated from the area altogether to make it easier for the many, many residents with respiratory diseases to move around the area. Pesticides should never be used anywhere. 'Weeds' are not a problem, but pesticides are. More vegetation in general would make the area a lot more pleasant to be in. Lights should have no flicker, ie. no LED lights or other flickering bulbs. They are dangerous to people with neurological disabilities. There should be no cell towers or antennas or other wireless installations (including 'Smart' meters!) anywhere in the neighborhood to protect residents and visitors from exposure.
column46: The number one priority in my neighborhood should be eliminating both chemical and electrosmog pollution!
column47: I'd like to see Telegraph Ave to be more like the pedestrian-only streets in many countries in Europe, where people feel welcome to gather. Some of those streets resemble parks, with more trees and vegetation. I'd also like to see streets more like those in East Germany, such as in downtown East Berlin, where there were very few, if any, cars on the road.
column48: Can't say it enough: Pollution is a major issue in this neighborhood. We're between a couple of freeways, and have massive traffic traveling through here. Less traffic on the streets would help tremendously. The city must stop using pesticides on our streets! There is no excuse for it. The city should join other cities, like Fairfax, in banning 'Smart' meters, and preventing any further siting of cell towers and antennas in our neighborhoods.

column44: designated bike lanes, but NOT shared-use lanes, as it is too busy of a transit corridor for those to provide any safety to cyclists. Especially on lower Telegraph Ave, i.e. 20th - 30th there's the most traffic congestion (paired with parked cars, too narrow of a space) and is the most dangerous part to bike on.
column46: Sounds great! I'm glad you're working on this.

column26: It connects Oakland and Berkeley directly. I like the shops and restaurants on parts of Telegraph.
column27: It's way too wide! It's dangerous to cross, there aren't bike lanes for much of it. Buses go fast and cars go really fast. I often worry about a car opening its door on me and knocking me into traffic. The pavement is broken and unsafe in some places (the stretch through Temescal, in particular). I have had many, many close calls on Telegraph Ave as a cyclist and pedestrian, though I'm not a risk taker and really do obey signals and rules. Still, I often feel it's only a matter of time before I get hurt. I also feel that the area would be much more vibrant and conducive to community life if Telegraph was narrowed. If people want to move fast and expeditiously, they can use any one of the nearby highways. I would like to see the speed limit lowered and much less car traffic.
column42: Slow the speeds down, narrow the road.

column46: Please prioritize walking and biking. The entire corridor will be improved because of this. I would like to see a narrowed Telegraph ave and one that is much slower and does not prioritize the needs of cars above all else.

column27: I wish it wasn't so wide. Much better ped crossings are needed. Better turning for bicyclists, too.
column46: It most absolutely has safety challenges for every single mode of transit. Ped crossings are generally pretty bad. Drivers speed along this corridor like crazy, in part because I think there are far too few stoplights.
column47: As both a car driver and cyclist, I can appreciate when both modes have their own designated space, it's just safer for everybody. The best I've ever seen that also doesn't affect parking much are separated bike lanes along the sidewalk (where parking would normally) be, then parking along the left side of the bike lane next to the traffic. This is such a better option than bike lanes sandwiched between the road and parked cars, and makes the sidewalks feel less cramped too. As for pedestrian crossings, I've never seen a more effective implementation of crosswalk lights than on MLK near Ashby BART. Those things work. Telegraph is wide enough and has so few stoplights that an illuminated, flashing signal is necessary for at least 3-4 of the major crossings.

column26: It's a great connector between Berkeley and Oakland, and it's relatively flat which is nice for cycling. There are lots of great restaurants and shops.

It's also not a very pleasant place to walk along despite there being so many wonderful businesses along Telegraph. It would be nice to see more traffic calming and beautification, for example parklets or more bike parking.

column44: the code of ethics and safety for cyclist and auto drivers have to be reviewed each month...there are speeding cars and commercial trucks..including the UPS...that drive very close to cyclist and there are cyclist that forget to wear their reflection vest or tape and light as safety indicator that they are in front..in back...turning left or right.....the one on each corner street lamps would serve best as aid for cyclist..strollers and shoppers on the busy Telegraph Avenue strip.
column45: Ease of crossing is all about having visible and tactile braill pads situated within ADA code height for persons w/ disabilities to cross..including the "Chirping Bird" device for signaling it is safe to cross. column46: I would de-emphasize bicycles - there are better options - a bike lane on a thoroughfare with traffic often at 45 mph+ is untenable, in general.   Buses need to learn to look for bikes if this is to continue.
column47: I think it's basically fine for cars - the trouble is making it safer for pedestrian crossing.  Bikes would be smarter to choose the existing bike paths like I mentioned above - College to Forest St to Claremont to Hillegass to Bowditch to campus - very bike safe and just as fast.  I often get to work faster on my bike than when I drive.
